summary: Daniel A. Parsons appears to be an individual who compiled notes and maintained files related to various individuals and operations, potentially involving the CIA and USIA. His notes, dated around May 1978, detail the career and assignments of an Air Force officer and reference individuals and operations, including possible links to the Penkovsky case. He also has connections to various organizations and individuals. The documents suggest Parsons was involved in indexing and file management, possibly within a context related to intelligence or government operations. One document mentions the transmittal of sanitized notes to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), suggesting a connection, albeit indirect, to the JFK assassination investigation.
significance: Daniel A. Parsons' significance in the JFK assassination context is indirect. His notes were sanitized and transmitted to the HSCA, indicating that information he possessed or compiled was deemed relevant to the investigation, specifically regarding individuals like William Alexander Morgan and George de Mohrenschildt. His role appears to be more of a collector and organizer of information rather than a direct participant in events related to the assassination.
